user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 8.13.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
If UT_StubTableEntry_t::Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr is declared as a plain char * (non-const), then the assignment StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr = TypeName; (where TypeName is const char *) discards the const qualifier and thus violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. The fix is to declare ContentTypeStr as const char * so the pointer points to a const-qualified type.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified UT_GetStubEntry code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/605.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_GetStubEntry:
```c
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified UT_GetStubEntry code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original UT_GetStubEntry with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as UT_GetStubEntry.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call UT_GetStubEntry to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of UT_GetStubEntry as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, UT_GetStubEntry will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of UT_GetStubEntry as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
